Definition: The input contains an argument and a keypoint on the topic "We should subsidize journalism", separated by "<sep>".Your task is to answer if the keypoint matches the argument and summarizes exactly what the argument means, in the context of this topic.

Positive Examples.input: Argument: Subsidizing journalism would give the government control over it<sep>Keypoint: It is preferable to spend the money elsewhere
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint does not summarize the argument that subsidizing journalism would give the government control over it

Positive Examples.input: Argument: We need journalists to keep us informed as to what is going on in the world<sep>Keypoint: Journalism is important to information-spreading/accountability
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that we need journalists to keep us informed as to what is going on in the world

Positive Examples.input: Argument: Subsidizing journalism would make it more efficient.<sep>Keypoint: Subsidies will increase the quality of journalism
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that subsidizing journalism would make it more efficient.

Negative Examples.input: Argument: We should subsidize journalism as it is a key element to investigating wrong doings in society<sep>Keypoint: A subsidy is important to make journalism viable
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint does not summarize the argument that we should subsidize journalism as it is a key element to investigating wrong doings in society

Negative Examples.input: Argument: Journalism subsidized by authoritarian regimes becomes a propaganda machine used to control people, telling them what to think and spreading lies to hide totalitarian regimes' abuses<sep>Keypoint: Government intervention has the risk of inserting bias/harming objectivity
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that journalism subsidized by authoritarian regimes becomes a propaganda machine used to control people, telling them what to think and spreading lies to hide totalitarian regimes' abuses

Negative Examples.input: Argument: Quality journalism is important it's the way we know what the people in power are doing. it's important to fund that.<sep>Keypoint: A subsidy is important to make journalism viable
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint does not summarize the argument that quality journalism is important it's the way we know what the people in power are doing. it's important to fund that.

Instances.input: Argument: Journalism must reach all citizens and the central government must ensure that information reaches all corners of the nation<sep>Keypoint: A subsidy is important to make journalism viable

Argument: Subsidizing journalism could raise questions about bias and editorial independence.<sep>Keypoint: Government intervention has the risk of inserting bias/harming objectivity
Argument: We should subsidize journalism because it will help guarantee good honest reporting.<sep>Keypoint: A subsidy is important to make journalism viable
Argument: We already are in high enough debt, we don't need to make it worse be subsidizing pointless things.<sep>Keypoint: It is preferable to spend the money elsewhere

Argument: There are many sectors need subsidizing more than journalism, journalists already make good money, more money to them will be a waste.<sep>Keypoint: Journalism is like every other business and if it is not sustainable it should fail

Argument: We should not subsidize journalism as they are private companies and can raise tons of money without our fear of bad reporting because their company would tank if they reported bad news.<sep>Keypoint: It is preferable to spend the money elsewhere

Argument: Knowledge is power and freedom, funding the public's access to high quality, trustworthy journalism is a worthy pursuit to enable a better equipped society<sep>Keypoint: Journalism is important to information-spreading/accountability

Argument: Subsidizing everything a person does can drain the pocket overtime.<sep>Keypoint: Journalism is like every other business and if it is not sustainable it should fail

Argument: Subsidizing journalism will lead to legislators threatening news agencies with taking their funding away if they report controversial content.<sep>Keypoint: Journalism is like every other business and if it is not sustainable it should fail

Argument: Non-trustworthy news sources and fake news stories abound. we must subsidize investigative journalism in order to ensure we have reliable news sources that report real facts.<sep>Keypoint: Subsidies will increase the quality of journalism
Argument: Better journalism is needed to keep our governments in check and the general population in the know<sep>Keypoint: Subsidy increases objectivity in reporting

Argument: Journalism is an important part of our political system; it keeps citizens informed and exposes government corruption.<sep>Keypoint: Subsidies will increase the quality of journalism
Argument: Journalism is important to ensure that the population is informed about important issues.<sep>Keypoint: A subsidy is important to make journalism viable
Argument: It is important to ensure that the public is able to receive the news.<sep>Keypoint: Journalism is important to information-spreading/accountability

Argument: We should subsidize journalism so they can do a lot of a better job in reporting news and what they are reporting can be controlled<sep>Keypoint: Subsidies will increase the quality of journalism
Argument: We should not subsidize journalism because a lot of the journalists spread false news<sep>Keypoint: It is preferable to spend the money elsewhere

Argument: Journalism is a public good, that it has broad social benefits far beyond that between buyer and seller, journalism need the resources to get it produced<sep>Keypoint: Subsidies will increase the quality of journalism
Argument: If journalism was subsidised it would encourage more inaccurate, poor quality work.<sep>Keypoint: Government intervention has the risk of inserting bias/harming objectivity

Argument: We should not subsidize journalism because it is a poor use of public money when things like healthcare and education are short of funding<sep>Keypoint: Journalism is like every other business and if it is not sustainable it should fail
Argument: The journalism won't be able to be trusted. it could be biased depending on who does the subsidising.<sep>Keypoint: It is preferable to spend the money elsewhere

Argument: When journalism is subsidized it is less likely they will report anything negative about the source they are receiving funding from therefore distorting the facts<sep>Keypoint: Government intervention has the risk of inserting bias/harming objectivity
Argument: Newspapers are dying and need the support.<sep>Keypoint: A subsidy is important to make journalism viable
Argument: Journalism is more important than ever in an era of fake news and social media.<sep>Keypoint: Subsidies will increase the quality of journalism
Argument: If journalism was subsidised it would encourage more inaccurate, poor quality work.<sep>Keypoint: It is preferable to spend the money elsewhere

Argument: Subsidizing journalism could cause them to not report only what the government (or whoever is paying the bill) will allow them to.<sep>Keypoint: It is preferable to spend the money elsewhere
Argument: If journalism is funded it would provide wider and better coverage therefore we would be better informed<sep>Keypoint: Subsidy increases objectivity in reporting

Argument: We already are in high enough debt, we don't need to make it worse be subsidizing pointless things.<sep>Keypoint: Journalism is like every other business and if it is not sustainable it should fail

Argument: Journalism should not be subsidized because subsidies could too easily be allotted according to political beliefs.<sep>Keypoint: Government intervention has the risk of inserting bias/harming objectivity
Argument: Subsidizing journalism allows more voices to be heard<sep>Keypoint: A subsidy is important to make journalism viable
Argument: Subsidizing journalism will lead to corruption, i.e. print the story the way i told you to or your funding is cut.<sep>Keypoint: It is preferable to spend the money elsewhere

Argument: Journalism is necessary to any society, to both report the news and keep people informed of important issues they may not be aware of otherwise.<sep>Keypoint: Journalism is important to information-spreading/accountability

Argument: Subsidizing journalism will lead to corruption, i.e. print the story the way i told you to or your funding is cut.<sep>Keypoint: Government intervention has the risk of inserting bias/harming objectivity
